div.p: [LibNote]53[/LibNote] I North Audley Street No longer -------------------------- ----- Riegate - ten oclock clock Friday night May 14[superscript]h 1841 My dear mother -- Fanny is here safe and sound and com fortably in bed in a very good [unclear] - and her head as low as she likes -- All right -- and she has had tea & eaten bread & butter & a bit of dry[underline] toast nicely buttered by no hands as you may guess but those of Blac[unclear][/unclear]ly- -black & Kindly -- friend - To be sure Lestock is the fondest & most tender of husbands & con- [insertion]gentle to her[underline][/underline] stantly [insertion]gentle gentle to [underline]her[/underline][/insertion] - But that is not what I was going to say - or you wanting to know [insertion](You impatient people I see and I hear you!)

Fanny is not nearly as much tired as I feared and I am sure as you feared she would be --- Perhaps however the bruise of tiredness may not appear immediately & I must wait till I see how she is in the morning -- However you
may as well have the pleasure of this good report while it is fresh & true -

We left London about five & twenty minutes before six and were here a quarter before 9 - three and twenty miles- - not quite half way to Brighton - seven and twenty miles further to Brighton [deletion][unclear]TSoc [deletion][/deletion] So we cannot yet look back on the hardest part & laugh - But we did smile often on the way hither, for it was a very good smooth road - one long hill to go down excepted she did not feel any inconvenience but the downhill motion pains

- The evening was delightful and all the air perfumed (too much for her taste) with hawthorn and lilacs & laburnams & Judas trees in such full flower & horse ches nuts in such full candalabra beauty - as she lay in the
carriage she could see some of these [deletion]and[/deletion] her dear cheerful ready to be pleased temper is charming! -

Lestock had contrived her diagonal couch so that she lay almost at full length her legs just humoring the thing. [Figure] "Je renonce a ça" myself and therefore I must leave that square with M, [insertion]a black blot [/insertion] to repre- sent [deletion]both[/deletion] my seat & myself- I am sorry to have made Lestock such a dumpy man - - But you may comprehend by these Scribbloglyphics of [unclear][/unclear] how we sat- tho not what like we were - Tell Dr Francis that the case wh[superscript]h[/superscript] he had made for my writing & dressing & work-box made my seat standing on end & put in a green-baize-bag & with a horse hair cushion [insertion]at tuppence [/insertion]for me to sit upon- Oh! exactly the thing! [deletion]&[/deletion] I had it made the day before by a charming man I went & [unclear]beseeched[/unclear] to and [underline]prayed[/underline] to about it in Oxford S[superscript]t[/superscript] - Honora directed me to him and he is [underline]impayable[/underline] but I paid him - & only 3/6 This part my skill to foreshorten 54
It was thought impossible that I could be squeezed into the carriage and so it would, have been, [underline]but [/underline]for this device & this darling [deletion]box of[/deletion] Case of - cases - never sat so comfortably [unclear][/unclear] FMWs [insertion]writing [/insertion]Box for footstool & all!

Barry joins us tomorrow by 3 o clock - waits till letters come in in London at 10 o clock in hopes of hearing from [underline]AB[/underline] - And when I know Harriet Butlers intentions as to coming I can settle [underline]his[/underline] HB - And when I know Harriet Butlers intentions as to coming I can settle mine as to going & will let you know [underline]mine[/underline] as to going & will [underline]let you [/underline]know We go to Hotel at Brighton first day, while Barry & Lestock house=hunt - The gentle Giant -ess, Mary, is with us - came with John the best of Johns [deletion](except[/deletion] ([underline]King John[/underline], (Lucy) always excepted for your sake)

- Ross and Lewen will come on Morrow to us & then we shall be ourselves again with all our North Audley comforts full upon us and I hope to be able [underline]to give[/underline] you a good [insertion]acct [/insertion]of Fanny tomorrow
div.closer: Good bye now dearest mother - I hope this will [underline]still[/underline] your anxiety, which I know [underline]must[/underline] be very great ) your affec at a [underline]distance! [/underline]when even Maria E mine on the spot was great enough
